get.description: get available API versions
get information of a group
get available resources
list or watch objects of kind Cluster

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description:
resourceVersion sets a constraint on what resource versions a request may be served from. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersion

parameters.description:
resourceVersionMatch determines how resourceVersion is applied to list calls. It is highly recommended that resourceVersionMatch be set for list calls where resourceVersion is set See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: Timeout for the list/watch call. This limits the duration of the call, regardless of any activity or inactivity.
parameters.name: timeoutSeconds

parameters.description: Watch for changes to the described resources and return them as a stream of add, update, and remove notifications. Specify resourceVersion.
parameters.name: watch

parameters.description: When present, indicates that modifications should not be persisted. An invalid or unrecognized dryRun directive will result in an error response and no further processing of the request. Valid values are: - All: all dry run stages will be processed
parameters.name: dryRun

parameters.description: fieldManager is a name associated with the actor or entity that is making these changes. The value must be less than or 128 characters long, and only contain printable characters, as defined by https://golang.org/pkg/unicode/#IsPrint.
parameters.name: fieldManager

parameters.description: The duration in seconds before the object should be deleted. Value must be non-negative integer. The value zero indicates delete immediately. parameters.description: Deprecated: please use the PropagationPolicy, this field will be deprecated in 1.7. Should the dependent objects be orphaned. If true/false, the "orphan" finalizer will be added to/removed from the object's finalizers list. Either this field or PropagationPolicy may be set, but not both.
parameters.name: orphanDependents

parameters.description: Whether and how garbage collection will be performed. Either this field or OrphanDependents may be set, but not both. The default policy is decided by the existing finalizer set in the metadata.finalizers and the resource-specific default policy. Acceptable values are: 'Orphan' - orphan the dependents; 'Background' - allow the garbage collector to delete the dependents in the background; 'Foreground' - a cascading policy that deletes all dependents in the foreground.
parameters.name: propagationPolicy

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: Timeout for the list/watch call. This limits the duration of the call, regardless of any activity or inactivity.
parameters.name: timeoutSeconds

parameters.description: If 'true', then the output is pretty printed.
parameters.name: pretty

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

Defaults to unset

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: When present, indicates that modifications should not be persisted. An invalid or unrecognized dryRun directive will result in an error response and no further processing of the request. Valid values are: - All: all dry run stages will be processed
parameters.name: dryRun

parameters.description: fieldManager is a name associated with the actor or entity that is making these changes. The value must be less than or 128 characters long, and only contain printable characters, as defined by https://golang.org/pkg/unicode/#IsPrint.
parameters.name: fieldManager

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: When present, indicates that modifications should not be persisted. An invalid or unrecognized dryRun directive will result in an error response and no further processing of the request. Valid values are: - All: all dry run stages will be processed
parameters.name: dryRun

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: The duration in seconds before the object should be deleted. Value must be non-negative integer. The value zero indicates delete immediately. If this value is nil, the default grace period for the specified type will be used. Defaults to a per object value if not specified. zero means delete immediately.
parameters.name: gracePeriodSeconds

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: Deprecated: please use the PropagationPolicy, this field will be deprecated in 1.7. Should the dependent objects be orphaned. If true/false, the "orphan" finalizer will be added to/removed from the object's finalizers list. Either this field or PropagationPolicy may be set, but not both.
parameters.name: orphanDependents

parameters.description: Whether and how garbage collection will be performed. Either this field or OrphanDependents may be set, but not both. The default policy is decided by the existing finalizer set in the metadata.finalizers and the resource-specific default policy. Acceptable values are: 'Orphan' - orphan the dependents; 'Background' - allow the garbage collector to delete the dependents in the background; 'Foreground' - a cascading policy that deletes all dependents in the foreground.
parameters.name: propagationPolicy

parameters.description:
resourceVersion sets a constraint on what resource versions a request may be served from. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersion

parameters.description:
resourceVersionMatch determines how resourceVersion is applied to list calls. It is highly recommended that resourceVersionMatch be set for list calls where resourceVersion is set See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: Timeout for the list/watch call. This limits the duration of the call, regardless of any activity or inactivity.
parameters.name: timeoutSeconds

parameters.description: If 'true', then the output is pretty printed.
parameters.name: pretty

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description:
resourceVersion sets a constraint on what resource versions a request may be served from. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersion

parameters.description:
resourceVersionMatch determines how resourceVersion is applied to list calls. It is highly recommended that resourceVersionMatch be set for list calls where resourceVersion is set See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: Timeout for the list/watch call. This limits the duration of the call, regardless of any activity or inactivity.
parameters.name: timeoutSeconds

parameters.description: Watch for changes to the described resources and return them as a stream of add, update, and remove notifications. Specify resourceVersion.

If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

resourceVersion sets a constraint on what resource versions a request may be served from. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersion

parameters.description:
resourceVersionMatch determines how resourceVersion is applied to list calls. It is highly recommended that resourceVersionMatch be set for list calls where resourceVersion is set See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: Timeout for the list/watch call. This limits the duration of the call, regardless of any activity or inactivity.
parameters.name: timeoutSeconds

parameters.description: Watch for changes to the described resources and return them as a stream of add, update, and remove notifications. Specify resourceVersion.
parameters.name: watch

parameters.description: When present, indicates that modifications should not be persisted. An invalid or unrecognized dryRun directive will result in an error response and no further processing of the request. Valid values are: - All: all dry run stages will be processed
parameters.name: dryRun

parameters.description: fieldManager is a name associated with the actor or entity that is making these changes. The value must be less than or 128 characters long, and only contain printable characters, as defined by https://golang.org/pkg/unicode/#IsPrint.
parameters.name: fieldManager

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: When present, indicates that modifications should not be persisted. An invalid or unrecognized dryRun directive will result in an error response and no further processing of the request. Valid values are: - All: all dry run stages will be processed
parameters.name: dryRun

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: The duration in seconds before the object should be deleted. Value must be non-negative integer. The value zero indicates delete immediately. If this value is nil, the default grace period for the specified type will be used. Defaults to a per object value if not specified. zero means delete immediately.
parameters.name: gracePeriodSeconds

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: Deprecated: please use the PropagationPolicy, this field will be deprecated in 1.7. Should the dependent objects be orphaned. If true/false, the "orphan" finalizer will be added to/removed from the object's finalizers list. Either this field or PropagationPolicy may be set, but not both.
parameters.name: orphanDependents

parameters.description: Whether and how garbage collection will be performed. Either this field or OrphanDependents may be set, but not both. The default policy is decided by the existing finalizer set in the metadata.finalizers and the resource-specific default policy. Acceptable values are: 'Orphan' - orphan the dependents; 'Background' - allow the garbage collector to delete the dependents in the background; 'Foreground' - a cascading policy that deletes all dependents in the foreground.
parameters.name: propagationPolicy

If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.name: name

get.description: watch individual changes to a list of ConfigMap. deprecated: use the 'watch' parameter with a list operation instead.

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
resourceVersion sets a constraint on what resource versions a request may be served from. See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersion

parameters.description:
resourceVersionMatch determines how resourceVersion is applied to list calls. It is highly recommended that resourceVersionMatch be set for list calls where resourceVersion is set See https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#resource-versions for details.

Defaults to unset
parameters.name: resourceVersionMatch

parameters.description: Timeout for the list/watch call. This limits the duration of the call, regardless of any activity or inactivity.
parameters.name: timeoutSeconds

parameters.description: Watch for changes to the described resources and return them as a stream of add, update, and remove notifications. Specify resourceVersion.
parameters.name: watch

get.description: watch individual changes to a list of Tiltfile. deprecated: use the 'watch' parameter with a list operation instead.

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: If 'true', then the output is pretty printed.
parameters.name: pretty

get.description: watch individual changes to a list of UISession. deprecated: use the 'watch' parameter with a list operation instead.

parameters.description: allowWatchBookmarks requests watch events with type "BOOKMARK". Servers that do not implement bookmarks may ignore this flag and bookmarks are sent at the server's discretion. Clients should not assume bookmarks are returned at any specific interval, nor may they assume the server will send any BOOKMARK event during a session. If this is not a watch, this field is ignored.
parameters.name: allowWatchBookmarks

parameters.description:
The continue option should be set when retrieving more results from the server. Since this value is server defined, clients may only use the continue value from a previous query result with identical query parameters (except for the value of continue) and the server may reject a continue value it does not recognize. If the specified continue value is no longer valid whether due to expiration (generally five to fifteen minutes) or a configuration change on the server, the server will respond with a 410 ResourceExpired error together with a continue token. If the client needs a consistent list, it must restart their list without the continue field. Otherwise, the client may send another list request with the token received with the 410 error, the server will respond with a list starting from the next key, but from the latest snapshot, which is inconsistent from the previous list results - objects that are created, modified, or deleted after the first list request will be included in the response, as long as their keys are after the "next key".

This field is not supported when watch is true. Clients may start a watch from the last resourceVersion value returned by the server and not miss any modifications.
parameters.name: continue

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their fields. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: fieldSelector

parameters.description: A selector to restrict the list of returned objects by their labels. Defaults to everything.
parameters.name: labelSelector

parameters.description:
limit is a maximum number of responses to return for a list call. If more items exist, the server will set the `continue` field on the list metadata to a value that can be used with the same initial query to retrieve the next set of results. Setting a limit may return fewer than the requested amount of items (up to zero items) in the event all requested objects are filtered out and clients should only use the presence of the continue field to determine whether more results are available. Servers may choose not to support the limit argument and will return all of the available results. If limit is specified and the continue field is empty, clients may assume that no more results are available. This field is not supported if watch is true.

The server guarantees that the objects returned when using continue will be identical to issuing a single list call without a limit - that is, no objects created, modified, or deleted after the first request is issued will be included in any subsequent continued requests. This is sometimes referred to as a consistent snapshot, and ensures that a client that is using limit to receive smaller chunks of a very large result can ensure they see all possible objects. If objects are updated during a chunked list the version of the object that was present at the time the first list result was calculated is returned.
parameters.name: limit

parameters.description: If 'true', then the output is pretty printed.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
ClusterSpec defines how to find the cluster we're running containers on.

Tilt currently supports connecting to an existing Kubernetes cluster or an existing Docker Daemon (for Docker Compose).

connection.description: Connection spec for an existing cluster.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ClusterStatus defines the observed state of Cluster

arch.description:
The preferred chip architecture of the cluster.

On Kubernetes, this will correspond to the kubernetes.io/arch annotation on a node.

On Docker, this will be the Architecture of the Docker daemon.

Note that many clusters support multiple chipsets. This field doesn't intend that this is the only architecture a cluster supports, only that it's one of the architectures.

connectedAt.description:
ConnectedAt indicates the time at which the cluster connection was established.

Consumers can use this to detect when the underlying config has changed and refresh their client/connection accordingly.

error.description: An unrecoverable error connecting to the cluster.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
Cmd represents a process on the host machine.

When the process exits, we will make a best-effort attempt (within OS limitations) to kill any spawned descendant processes.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdImageSpec describes how the custom script builds images and where it puts them.

args.description: Command-line arguments. Must have length at least 1.

dir.description:
Process working directory.

If the working directory is not specified, the command is run in the default Tilt working directory.

imageMaps.description:
Names of image maps that this build depends on.

The controller will watch all the image maps, and rebuild the image if any of the maps resolve to a new image.

outputMode.description: Specifies where the image is built. If not specified, we assume the image was built to the local Docker image store.

outputTag.description:
Tag we expect the image to be built with (we use this to check that the expected image+tag has been created).

If empty, we create an expected tag at the beginning of CustomBuild (and export $EXPECTED_REF=name:expected_tag )

outputsImageRefTo.description:
Specifies a filepath where the cmd script prints the result image ref.

Tilt will read it out when we're done to find the image.

ref.description: The named reference of the image.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdImageStateBuilding expresses that an image build is in-progress.

reason.description: The reason why the image is building.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdImageStateCompleted expresses when the image build is finished and no new images need to be built.

error.description: Error message if the build failed.

finishedAt.description: Time when we finished building an image

reason.description: The reason why the image was built.

startedAt.description: Time when we started building an image.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdImageStateWaiting expresses what we're waiting on to build an image.

reason.description: (brief) reason the image build is waiting.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdImageStatus describes the result of the image build.

completed.description: Details about a finished image build.

ref.description:
A fully-qualified image reference of a built image, as seen from the local network.

Usually includes a name and an immutable tag.

NB: If we're building to a particular registry, this may have a different hostname from the Spec `Ref` field.

waiting.description: Details about a waiting image build.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdList

Servers should convert recognized schemas to the latest internal value, and may reject unrecognized values. com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdSpec defines how to run a local command.

args.description: Command-line arguments. Must have length at least 1.

dir.description:
Process working directory.

If the working directory is not specified, the command is run in the default Tilt working directory.

env.description:
Additional variables process environment.

Expressed as a C-style array of strings of the form ["KEY1=VALUE1", "KEY2=VALUE2", ...].

Environment variables are layered on top of the environment variables that Tilt runs with.

restartOn.description:
Indicates objects that can trigger a restart of this command.

When a restart is triggered, Tilt will try to gracefully shutdown any currently running process, waiting for it to exit before starting a new process. If the process doesn't shutdown within the allotted time, Tilt will kill the process abruptly.

Restarts can happen even if the command is already done.

Logs of the current process after the restart are discarded.

startOn.description:
Indicates objects that can trigger a start/restart of this command.

Restarts behave the same as RestartOn. The key difference is that a Cmd with any StartOn triggers will not have its command run until its StartOn is satisfied.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdStateRunning is a running state of a local command.

pid.description: The process id of the command.

startedAt.description: Time at which the command was last started.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdStateTerminated is a terminated state of a local command.

exitCode.description: Exit status from the last termination of the command

finishedAt.description: Time at which the command last terminated

pid.description: The process id of the command.

reason.description: (brief) reason the process is terminated

startedAt.description: Time at which previous execution of the command started

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: CmdStateWaiting is a waiting state of a local command.

reason.description: (brief) reason the process is not yet running.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
CmdStatus defines the observed state of Cmd

Based loosely on ContainerStatus in Kubernetes

disableStatus.description: Details about whether/why this is disabled.

ready.description:
Specifies whether the command has passed its readiness probe.

Terminating the command does not change its Ready state.

Is always true when no readiness probe is defined.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
ConfigMap stores unstructured data that other controllers can read and write.

Useful for sharing data from one system and subscribing to it from another.

key.description: The key where the enable/disable state is stored.

name.description: The name of the ConfigMap

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: Describes how a ToggleButton's state is stored in a ConfigMap. The ConfigMap must be created separately - the ToggleButton will not automatically create it.

name.description: Name of the ConfigMap

offValue.description: ConfigMap value corresponding to the button's "off" state If not specified, "false" will be used.

onValue.description: ConfigMap value corresponding to the button's "on" state. If not specified, "true" will be used.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
Container is an init or application container within a pod.

The Tilt API representation mirrors the Kubernetes API very closely. Irrelevant data is not included, and some fields might be simplified.

There might also be Tilt-specific status fields.

id.description: ID is the normalized container ID (the `docker://` prefix is stripped).

image.description: Image is the image the container is running.

name.description: Name is the name of the container as defined in Kubernetes.

ports.description:
Ports are exposed ports as extracted from the Pod spec.

This is added by Tilt for convenience when managing port forwards.

ready.description: Ready is true if the container is passing readiness checks (or has none defined).

restarts.description:
Restarts is the number of times the container has restarted.

This includes restarts before the Tilt daemon was started if the container was already running.

state.description: State provides details about the container's current condition.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ContainerLogStreamStatus defines the current status of each individual container log stream.

active.description: True when the stream is set up and streaming logs properly.

error.description:
The last error message encountered while streaming.

Empty when the stream is actively streaming or successfully terminated.

name.description: The name of the container.

terminated.description: True when the logs are done stream and the container is terminated.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
ContainerState holds a possible state of container.

Only one of its members may be specified. If none of them is specified, the default one is ContainerStateWaiting.

running.description: Running provides details about a currently executing container.

terminated.description: Terminated provides details about an exited container.

waiting.description: Waiting provides details about a container that is not yet running.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ContainerStateRunning is a running state of a container.

startedAt.description: StartedAt is the time the container began running.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ContainerStateTerminated is a terminated state of a container.

exitCode.description:
ExitCode is the exit status from the termination of the container.

Any non-zero value indicates an error during termination.

finishedAt.description: FinishedAt is the time the container stopped running.

reason.description: Reason is a (brief) reason the container stopped running.

startedAt.description: StartedAt is the time the container began running.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ContainerStateWaiting is a waiting state of a container.

reason.description: Reason is a (brief) reason the container is not yet running.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: Aggregated disable status of DisableSources that belong to a resource.

disabledCount.description: How many of the resource's sources are disabled.

enabledCount.description: How many of the resource's sources are enabled.

sources.description: All unique sources that control the resource's objects' disable status.

state.description: Whether this is currently disabled (if known)

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: Points at a thing that can control whether something is disabled

configMap.description: This DisableSource is controlled by a ConfigMap

disabled.description: Whether this is currently disabled. Deprecated in favor of `State`.

lastUpdateTime.description: The last time this status was updated.

reason.description: The reason this status was updated.

state.description: Whether this is currently disabled (if known)

host.description:
The docker host to use.

If not specified, will read the DOCKER_HOST env or use the default docker host.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: DockerImage describes an image to build with Docker.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
DockerImageSpec describes how to build a Docker image with `docker_build`.

Most fields of this spec directly correspond to the Docker CLI.

args.description:
Args specifies the build arguments to the Dockerfile.

Equivalent to `--build-arg` in the docker CLI.

Each item should take the form "KEY" or "KEY=VALUE".

cacheFrom.description:
Images to use as cache sources.

Equivalent to `--cache-from` in the Docker CLI.

context.description:
Context specifies the Docker build context.

Must be an absolute path on the local filesystem.

dockerfileContents.description: Dockerfile contains the complete contents of the Dockerfile.

extraTags.description:
By default, Tilt creates a new temporary image reference for each build. The user can also specify their own reference, to integrate with other tooling (like build IDs for Jenkins build pipelines)

Equivalent to the docker build --tag flag.

imageMaps.description:
Names of image maps that this build depends on.

The controller will watch all the image maps, rebuild the image if any of the maps resolve to a new image, and inject them into the dockerfile.

network.description:
Set the networking mode for the RUN instructions in the docker build.

Equivalent to `--network` in the Docker CLI.

platform.description:
Platform specifies architecture information for target image.

https://docs.docker.com/desktop/multi-arch/

Equivalent to `--platform` in the Docker CLI.

pull.description:
Always attempt to pull a new version of the base image.

Equivalent to `--pull` in the Docker CLI.

ref.description: The named reference of the image.

secrets.description:
Pass secrets to docker.

https://docs.docker.com/develop/develop-images/build_enhancements/#new-docker-build-secret-information

Equivalent to `--secret` in the Docker CLI.

sshAgentConfigs.description:
Pass SSH secrets to docker so it can clone private repos.

https://docs.docker.com/develop/develop-images/build_enhancements/#using-ssh-to-access-private-data-in-builds

Equivalent to `--ssh` in the docker CLI.

target.description:
Target specifies the name of the stage in the Dockerfile to build.

Equivalent to `--target` in the docker CLI.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
DockerImageStageStatus gives detailed report of each stage of the most recent image build.

Most stages are derived from Buildkit's StatusResponse https://github.com/moby/buildkit/blob/35fcb28a009d6454b2915a5c8084b25ad851cf38/api/services/control/control.proto#L108 but Tilt may synthesize its own stages for the steps it owns.

Stages may be executed in parallel.

cached.description: Whether Buildkit was able to cache the stage based on inputs.

error.description: Error message if the stage failed. If empty, the stage succeeded.

finishedAt.description: The timetsamp when we completed the work on the stage.

name.description: A human-readable name of the stage.

startedAt.description: The timestamp when we started working on the stage.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: DockerImageStateBuilding expresses that an image build is in-progress.

reason.description: The reason why the image is building.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: DockerImageStateCompleted expresses when the image build is finished and no new images need to be built.

error.description: Error message if the build failed.

finishedAt.description: Time when we finished building an image

reason.description: The reason why the image was built.

startedAt.description: Time when we started building an image.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: DockerImageStateWaiting expresses what we're waiting on to build an image.

reason.description: (brief) reason the image build is waiting.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: DockerImageStatus defines the observed state of DockerImage

completed.description: Details about a finished image build.

ref.description:
A fully-qualified image reference of a built image, as seen from the local network.

Usually includes a name and an immutable tag.

NB: If we're building to a particular registry, this may have a different hostname from the Spec `Ref` field.

stageStatuses.description: Status information about each individual build stage of the most recent image build.

waiting.description: Details about a waiting image build.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ExecAction describes a "run in container" action.

command.description: Command is the command line to execute inside the container, the working directory for the command  is root ('/') in the container's filesystem. The command is simply exec'd, it is not run inside a shell, so traditional shell instructions ('|', etc) won't work. To use a shell, you need to explicitly call out to that shell. Exit status of 0 is treated as live/healthy and non-zero is unhealthy.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ExtensionRepoSpec defines how to access the repo.

ref.description: A reference to sync the repo to. If empty, Tilt will always update the repo to the latest version.

url.description:
The URL of the repo.

Allowed: https: URLs that point to a public git repo file: URLs that point to a location on disk.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ExtensionRepoStatus defines the observed state of ExtensionRepo

checkoutRef.description: The reference that we currently have checked out. On git, this is the commit hash. On file repos, this is empty.

error.description: Contains information about any problems loading the repo.

lastFetchedAt.description: The last time the repo was fetched and checked for validity.

path.description: The path to the repo on local disk.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ExtensionSpec defines the desired state of Extension

args.description:
Arguments to the Tiltfile loaded by this extension.

Arguments can be positional (['a', 'b', 'c']) or flag-based ('--to-edit=a'). By default, a list of arguments indicates the list of services in the tiltfile that should be enabled.

repoName.description:
RepoName specifies the ExtensionRepo object where we should find this extension.

The Extension controller should watch for changes to this repo, and may update if this repo is deleted or moved.

repoPath.description:
RepoPath specifies the path to the extension directory inside the repo.

Once the repo is downloaded, this path should point to a directory with a Tiltfile as the main "entrypoint" of the extension.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ExtensionStatus defines the observed state of Extension

error.description: Contains information about any problems loading the extension.

path.description: The path to the extension on disk. This location should be shared and readable by all Tilt instances.

seenFiles.description: SeenFiles is a list of paths which changed (create, modify, or delete).

time.description:
Time is an approximate timestamp for a batch of file changes.

This will NOT exactly match any inode attributes (e.g. ctime, mtime) at the filesystem level and is purely informational or for use as an opaque watermark.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: FileWatchSpec defines the desired state of FileWatch

ignores.description: Ignores are optional rules to filter out a subset of changes matched by WatchedPaths.

watchedPaths.description: WatchedPaths are paths of directories or files to watch for changes to. It cannot be empty.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: FileWatchStatus defines the observed state of FileWatch

disableStatus.description: Details about whether/why this is disabled.

error.description: Error is set if there is a problem with the filesystem watch. If non-empty, consumers should assume that no filesystem events will be seen and that the file watcher is in a failed state.

fileEvents.description: FileEvents summarizes batches of file changes (create, modify, or delete) that have been seen in ascending chronological order. Only the most recent 20 events are included.

lastEventTime.description:
LastEventTime is the timestamp of the most recent file event. It is zero if no events have been seen yet.

If the specifics of which files changed are not important, this field can be used as a watermark without needing to inspect FileEvents.

monitorStartTime.description: MonitorStartTime is the timestamp of when filesystem monitor was started. It is zero if the monitor has not been started yet.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: Forward defines a port forward to execute on a given pod.

containerPort.description: The port on the Kubernetes pod to connect to. Required.

host.description: Optional host to bind to on the current machine (localhost by default)

localPort.description:
The port to expose on the current machine.

If not specified (or 0), a random free port will be chosen and can be discovered via the status once established.

name.description: Name to identify this port forward.

path.description: Path to include as part of generated links for port forward.

addresses.description:
Addresses that the forwarder is bound to.

For example, a `localhost` host will bind to 127.0.0.1 and [::1].

containerPort.description: ContainerPort is the port in the container being forwarded.

error.description: Error is a human-readable description if a problem was encountered while initializing the forward.

localPort.description: LocalPort is the port bound to on the system running Tilt.

startedAt.description:
StartedAt is the time at which the forward was initiated.

If the forwarder is not running yet, this will be zero/empty.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: HTTPGetAction describes an action based on HTTP Get requests.

host.description: Host name to connect to, defaults to the pod IP. You probably want to set "Host" in httpHeaders instead.

httpHeaders.description: Custom headers to set in the request. HTTP allows repeated headers.

path.description: Path to access on the HTTP server.

port.description: Name or number of the port to access on the container. Number must be in the range 1 to 65535.

scheme.description: Scheme to use for connecting to the host. Defaults to HTTP.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: HTTPHeader describes a custom header to be used in HTTP probes

name.description: The header field name

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: Describes sets of file paths that the FileWatch should ignore.

basePath.description:
BasePath is the base path for the patterns. It cannot be empty.

If no patterns are specified, everything under it will be recursively ignored.

patterns.description:
Patterns are dockerignore style rules. Absolute-style patterns will be rooted to the BasePath.

See https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/#dockerignore-file.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
ImageMap expresses the mapping from an image reference to a real, pushed image in an image registry that a container runtime can access.

Another way to think about the ImageMap is that ImageMapSpec is a mutable image reference (where the image might not exist yet), but ImageMapStatus is an immutable image reference (where, if an image is specified, it always exists).

ImageMap does not specify how the image is built or who is responsible for building this. But any API that builds images should produce an ImageMap.

For example, a builder that builds to a local image registry might create a map from: 'my-apiserver:dev' to 'localhost:5000/my-apiserver:content-based-label'.

ImageMap doesn't follow the usual Kubernetes-style API semantics (where the Status is the result of running the Spec). It's closer to a ConfigMap. Though the Status does represent a real runtime result (an image in a registry).

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
ImageMapArgsOverride defines args to inject when the image is injected. Only applies to types that embed a v1.Container with a Command field.

https://pkg.go.dev/k8s.io/api/core/v1#Container

ImageMapCommandOverride defines a command to inject when the image is injected. Only applies to types that embed a v1.Container with a Command field.

https://pkg.go.dev/k8s.io/api/core/v1#Container
ImageMapSpec defines the desired state of ImageMap

matchExact.description: If specified, then tags on both the selector and the matched reference are used for matching. The selector will only match the reference if the tags match exactly.

matchInEnvVars.description: If specified, then the selector will also match any strings in container env variables.

overrideArgs.description: If specified, the injector will replace the 'args' field in the container when it replaces the image.

overrideCommand.description: If specified, the injector will replace the 'command' field in the container when it replaces the image.

selector.description:
A named image reference.

Deployment tools expect this image reference to match an image in the YAML being deployed, and will replace that image reference.

By default, this selector will match an image if the names match (tags on both the selector and the matched reference are ignored).

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description: ImageMapStatus defines the observed state of ImageMap

buildStartTime.description:
Timestamp indicating when the image started building.

Intended to be used to determine which file changes were picked up by the image build. We can assume that any file changes before this timestamp were definitely included in the image, and any file changes after this timestamp may not be included in the image.

image.description:
A fully-qualified image reference, including a name and an immutable tag, as seen from the cluster container runtime that we're mapping this image to.

NB: Container images often need to be referenced from different networks, including:

1) The cluster container runtime 2) The local network 3) The cluster network

And each of these cases may have distinct URLs. We might deprecate this field and only use fields of the form `ImageFromX`.

For more details on image references in different networks, see: https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/tree/master/keps/sig-cluster-lifecycle/generic/1755-communicating-a-local-registry#specification-for-localregistryhosting-v1

imageFromCluster.description: A fully-qualified image reference, including a name and an immutable tag, as seen from the cluster container runtime.

imageFromLocal.description: A fully-qualified image reference, including a name and an immutable tag, as seen from the local network.

com.github.tilt-dev.tilt.pkg.apis.core.v.description:
KubernetesApply specifies a blob of YAML to apply, and a set of ImageMaps that the YAML depends on.

The KubernetesApply controller will resolve the ImageMaps into immutable image references. The controller will process the spec YAML, then apply it to the cluster. Those processing steps might include:

- Injecting the resolved image references. - Adding custom labels so that Tilt can track the progress of the apply. - Modifying image pull rules to ensure the image is pulled correctly.

The controller won't apply anything until all ImageMaps resolve to real images.

The controller will watch all the image maps, and redeploy the entire YAML if any of the maps resolve to a new image.

The status field will contain both the raw applied object, and derived fields to help other controllers figure out how to watch the apply progress.

args.description: Args are the command-line arguments for the apply command. Must have length >= 1.

dir.description:
Process working directory.

If not specified, will default to Tilt working directory.

env.description:
Env are additional variables for the process environment.

Environment variables are layered on top of the environment variables that Tilt runs with.
